Another question for the group: What is the impact of the various other items on the legislative agenda on the impeachment vote?  There is must-pass (and some want-to-pass) legislation that requires Senate approval and President's signature by year end. I can envision that playing out several ways: 
1) Agree/2019: Democrats and Republicans reach behind-the-scenes agreement on 2019 passage of impeachment as part of a bigger package: 20% Pros: There are news reports that the sides are in discussions. Trump and Senate Republicans are saying publicly that they want impeachment passed ASAP. Cons: if there is agreement it would typically be at the 11th hour. there don't seem to be many signs I can see of the sides coming together on a plan.
2) Agree/2020: D&R delay impeachment vote into 2020 in order to get other items done: 30%
3) No agreement/2019: D&R deadlock and cannot agree on any of the above and D press ahead with passing articles without agreement on the other items: 35% Pros: That seems to be the train we're on. D Base is demanding it. Passing impeachment could reduce Trump's negotiating power. This could simply mean that the impeachment and shutdown talks aren't linked. Cons: Why would the Democrats not use this as a bargaining chip? 
4) No agreement/2020: D&R deadlock and D extend articles into 2020; 15%. Pros: this would appear to make sense if the Democrats believe that impeachment is a useful bargaining chip in the ongoing discussions on the other items. Cons: there is no real evidence to suggest that this option is in play.  At the top level I'm calling the odds of some kind of a agreement by the end of 2019 something like 50/50. However, these debates normally take up to the 11th (or 13th) hour which would not give enough time for passage of articles.  I don't have any solid intellectual basis for the odds above so I just spitballed it. Maybe a useful reference class would be past funding/shutdown votes.  This analysis gives a 55% chance to the odds but coming from another direction. At this point I don't have enough conviction in this thought process to change my current estimate of 70%.  Thoughts?

What are the merits and demerits of the House passing articles of impeachment by December 20 versus waiting 18 days beyond December 20 and voting on or after January 7? *The Democrats are not forced to act before December 31, as they will not lose authority or power to pass articles of impeachment.  *Passing them in December carries the risk of appearance of rushing things with voters.  *A basic business principle is to never exercise an option early. Passing articles in December passes control of the process to the Senate. Are the Democratic House Members ready for this? I think it will be hard for them to let go. It is sticky for them. They will have to be sure that they have more to gain by passing articles than by not passing them. I don't see a strong signal on this point yet.  *The Democrats may calculate that passing articles in December will damage the President's case. However, he is calling their bluff by encouraging the House to pass articles quickly to that the Senate trial can get underway.  *Republicans are running ads in the districts of vulnerable House members. Passing articles won't stop this. *Democrats have to be absolutely sure that all Democratic House Members will fall in line and vote for articles of impeachment. This seems sure, but they have to check and double-check. It would be embarrassing and counterproductive to have a couple jump ship. They must also be considering whether they can get any Republicans to flip. One could think that either of these reasons would drive the Democrats to delay if they can get a stronger more compelling vote. I don't know if they can, but it is worth considering.  *The polls showing support for impeachment have hardly changed. The House public hearings haven't changed minds. I don't think more public meetings will change any minds. This supports voting on articles in December unless the House Democrats believe that they can get the attention of voters in January and persuade some.  *The next Democratic debate is scheduled or December 19. Which candidates will benefit the most from a December 19 or earlier impeachment versus January? Is this relevant? *There is a 7% probability that the Senate will remove President Trump from office (See Crowd Forecast from today @ https://www.gjopen.com/questions/1290-when-will-donald-trump-cease-to-be-president-of-the-united-states). This creates the circularity in the question of why now in December rather than January or later? Given the low probability of removal by the Senate, it seems more beneficial to the Democrats to draw out the process longer as this has the better opportunity to harm President Trump's chances or reelection.  I am probably heavily into Vizzini-style reasoning, so will stop here. Any slick pundit would forecast this question as close to 50% as possible, as this is the safest zone in prediction markets because you can always explain why you were a few % off if the outcome goes the other way. Hats off to those taking a definitive logical fact-based position on either end of the probability continuum.

Will the Dems wrap things up before the end of December? One advantage of wrapping things up now is that the upcoming holidays and the superbowl will somewhat distract people from the Republican onslaught that's almost certain to be unleashed. Another advantage is that it'll allow Dems time to asses and repair the damage, if any, that these attacts are likely to have on its field of candidates. Will Biden be hurt in the primaries? Will Bernie benefit? Or will the sum of all establishment Democrats' fears occur, Tulsi surges in the polls? But waiting until sometime after December has the advantage of keeping the charges in the news until around March, which is the official beginning of the primary season. So, waiting may give the "favored" candidates a chance to build up a head of steam that they'll need to withstand the Republican storm. Of course, I'm assuming that these two senarios are the most important in determining when to complete the articles of impeachment. But the calendar may prove to be the thing that makes the difference.

I believe there is a high probability that at least one article of impeachment will pass the house in this timeline based primarily on comparisons with the Clinton impeachment trial. In the Clinton trial, changes to the scope of the impeachment investigation were made Dec 1, 1998 and a house vote on impeachment was still held by Dec 19. Question for the group: I find it interesting that PredictIt and GJOpen tell slightly different stories here. PredictIt has been pretty much flat, trading in a range from around 35% to 48% since the beginning of September. 3.1M shared traded GJOpen started out lower in the beginning of October and has drifted upward, now running more-or-less in that same range. 173 forecasters, 551 total forecasts. Based on the much larger participation numbers and the fact that they seem to have eventually converged, I'll take PredictIt as the more accurate gauge of the consensus of forecasters: ~45% and holding steady since September. So my question is: Since early September a lot has changed and the odds remain hovering in the middle. That tells me that despite all the ups and downs of the daily news, forecasters are still, as a group, about where they were in September. That seems odd to me.  Clearly there will always be a bias traceable to people's underlying political beliefs. Given that the country is more-or-less evenly split, I'm going to guess that pushes the result towards the middle unless there is overwhelming evidence one way or the other. Within that middle range it will be driven by the daily news (i.e. noise) and by people thinking through rational theories.  What are the dominant theories? I think most arguments fall into one of these buckets:  1) YES: The train has left the station and isn't stoppable now. The Democratic base is so fired up / so convinced that this is their moral duty that Pelosi has to push through articles regardless of what the Senate will do. If they don't push back on Trump then voters will punish them in the fall.
        For: Democrats have thus far kept on message, stayed focused on one issue and stayed on schedule. This is what the news media is saying and seems to be center of gravity opinion among the pundits on various sides of the political spectrum. History (e.g. Benghazi) shows that you can keep starting new investigations forever despite a lack of public support and maybe eventually the public will come around. 
        Against: Passing articles that are rejected by the Senate may leave the Democrats at the mercy of an uncontrollable president; better to keep investigating and keep him against the ropes.
         Odds: 60% change that this turns out to be correct
2) YES: Democrats feel that passing articles now (before 2020) will insulate them from accusations that they are passing articles in an election year which might boomerang on them in red and purple districts in November. 
         For: This is an argument being promoted mostly on the right (of course, because it isn't favorable for the left)
         Against: perhaps true, but this isn't the primary driving factor in determining an outcome
         Odds: 5%. I don't think this is driving the dialog
3) NO: Giving away control of the news cycle is too valuable. They will keep investigating wherever the new facts lead them until Trump is out of office one way or another. In mid to late December they will discover "new" and "shocking" evidence that "forces" them to push the investigation into the new year. etc. etc.
       For: If they pass impeachment and it loses in the Senate, it seems harder to get public support for future investigations. Controlling the news cycle through much of 2020 seems like a strong strategic position to be in coming up to an election.
       Against: There isn't much hard evidence to support this theory as of now. The democrats could start investigations. 
       Odds: 30%
4) NO: The fact that the Senate won't convict makes some democrats (especially in red to purple districts) in the house unwilling to vote to support impeachment so it might not pass. Pelosi cannot take the chance of having the vote fail in the house based on Democratic votes or even having a significant minority vote against it.
        Pros and Cons: this is math and presumably other people have done that math and concluded that this isn't a major issue since it isn't discussed much. 
        Odds: 5%
5) Are there others?  Thus far I have been most in camp #3. However, laying it out it does seem that #1 has the preponderance of the evidence. Am I falling prey to Plan Continuance Bias? Hedging my bet to 65% to reflect the analysis above.

Belief perseverance (also known as conceptual conservatism[1]) is maintaining a belief despite new information that firmly contradicts it.[2] Such beliefs may even be strengthened when others attempt to present evidence debunking them, a phenomenon known as the backfire effect (compare boomerang effect).[3] For example, journalist Cari Romm, in a 2014 article in The Atlantic, describes a study in which a group of people, concerned of the side effects of flu shots, became less willing to receive them after being told that the vaccination was entirely safe.[4] Since rationality involves conceptual flexibility,[5][6] belief perseverance is consistent with the view that human beings act at times in an irrational manner. Philosopher F.C.S. Schiller holds that belief perseverance "deserves to rank among the fundamental 'laws' of nature".[7]
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belief_perseverance#:~:targetText=Belief%20perseverance%20(also%20known%20as,effect%20(compare%20boomerang%20effect).

Confirmation bias is the tendency to search for, interpret, favor, and recall information in a way that affirms one's prior beliefs or hypotheses.[1] It is a type of cognitive bias and a systematic error of inductive reasoning.

Before 1 January 2020, will the U.S. House of Representatives pass an article of impeachment against President Trump?
Hattip to @GL2814 for reminding me that a procedure must be followed and it all takes time.

The following series of steps must now be taken for the inquiry to proceed to a full House impeachment vote: ISSUE A REPORT
The House resolution that authorized the public phase of the impeachment inquiry on Oct. 31 directed the House Intelligence Committee to issue a report laying out its findings and any recommendations. The report is to be prepared in consultation with the other two investigating committees: Foreign Affairs and Oversight. TO JUDICIARY COMMITTEE
Once complete, Representative Adam Schiff, the chair of the Intelligence Committee, is then meant to transmit the report, along with relevant evidentiary material and member views, to the Judiciary Committee and to release it publicly. Legislative sources had hoped the Intelligence Committee could complete its report and send it to the Judiciary Committee before the Nov. 28 U.S. Thanksgiving holiday, though it is unclear if they will succeed. MORE HEARINGS?
The House resolution has authorized the Judiciary Committee at this stage to conduct more proceedings if needed, including more hearings, that allow Trump and his counsel to participate. The ranking Republican on the Judiciary Committee, Doug Collins, can also subpoena witnesses, records and other material but only with the concurrence of the chairman, Democrat Jerrold Nadler. If the chairman and ranking member do not agree, the Republican can ask for a full committee vote. TO IMPEACH, OR NOT TO IMPEACH?
The Judiciary Committee has to decide if there is enough evidence to impeach. If it concludes that impeachment is warranted, the panel would draft articles of impeachment against Trump for a full House vote. OVER TO THE SENATE
If the House votes to impeach, the process then moves to the Republican-controlled Senate. Its options are to vote to dismiss the charges against Trump or to hold a trial. At this point, it seems likely to hold a trial because Republicans appear not to have the votes to dismiss the charges. “Most everybody agreed there’s not 51 votes to dismiss,” Republican Senator Lindsey Graham, a Trump ally, told reporters after he attended a White House meeting with White House Counsel Pat Cipollone on Thursday. Senate aides have said that some in the White House believe a full trial that acquitted Trump would be a better outcome than the charges being dismissed without the case first being presented to senators.
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-impeachment-steps-factbox/what-comes-next-in-the-trump-impeachment-inquiry-idUSKBN1XW24P

House Intelligence has to write a report of its findings - which it can do during the November recess.
HI also has to pass its info - open door and closed door testimony - to House Judiciary in some indexed & searchable fashion - which can also be worked upon during November recess.
HJ will probably formally receive all this on Dec 3 - first day the House is back in session. That's one day.
They will probably want a public hearing where Schiff and others will formally present HI's findings. That's two days.
Maybe here HJ might roll into debate and witnesses on what is an impeachable offense and the role of both houses of Congress - which eats up another day
Then HJ has to have a formal consideration of any articles themselves - I imagine this also is in open session. That's probably another two days.
Extra time would be needed on the articles themselves, and possible cross-chamber collaboration. Another day?
Then HJ would vote on the articles, and send any articles to the full House. This can be done in one day - but it's still one full day.
Upon which the Speaker will schedule debate, limit time frame for same, and ultimately, schedule and hold a floor vote. This looks like a three day process minimum. I count a best-case of 11 legislative days.
There are 8 work days left in 2019.
The House can be held back for the calendar week of Dec 16-20 - so there is a nominal runway for a 2019 completion.

The thing that catches my attention is that the Democrats are being very disciplined in just sticking to the Ukraine call matter and resisting what must be very powerful pulls down various other lines of investigation. That approach does not fit well with my prior mental model of what's going on. I assume Pelosi has a good answer but they've done a good job of keeping it out of the headlines. From where I sit on the sidelines that looks like an odd strategy. Here are the most likely game plans that Pelosi might be following that could explain this narrow approach: 
1) Pelosi plans to pass impeachment quickly on this narrow issue and get a quick non-conviction in the Senate, then open a new investigation in the new year. This approach would infuriate the Republicans and please the Democratic base. Both of those are good things if you're Pelosi. However, it seems to me that it would be risky for independents unless the Democrats know of a really strong line of investigation (tax returns?) that isn't really on the popular radar at the moment; OR 
2) Plan to get through this round of interviews, see where the polls and facts are and then, depending on the mood of the county, either decide to push for an impeachment vote immediately; do another round of interviews and dig deeper and have an impeachment vote in the new year; or open up some new line of a broader investigation and push this out well into 2020. Both of these scenarios seem plausible to me. I think both scenarios have risks for the Democrats. Scenario 2 seems like the more likely to allow them to continue to control the news cycle and minimize risk. I think there's a 10% chance that option 1 is in play, 60% chance that option 2 is in play and 30% chance that some other option I'm not considering is going on behind the scenes.  If Pelosi is following game plan 1, then I see a 50%/50% chance of getting impeachment passed by year end. => 5%
If game plan 2 is in play, then I see a 10% chance of getting impeachment by year end => 5%
In the "other" bucket i think there is a low likelihood of passing impeachment by year end => 1%
I should add that there could also be extrinsic factors that cause Democrats to push this, like some major new push from Trump where they feel their hand is forced to keep control of the news cycle. => 5% Total: ~15%

From there the impeachment process would move over to the Senate, which under current rules would be required to conduct a trial that could take weeks to complete. In my opinion, time is the critical factor here. How probable is it, that a vote will be held before the new year? Days to go.
Looking at the congressional calendar, there are only 18 days left on which the house will be in session before January 1st. These are: two days in October, eight days in November and eight days in the first two weeks of December. The last day the house will be in session, is on December 12th. Barring any changes to the congressional calendar, there are only 41calendar days left to prepare and put an article of impeachment before the house in their last session of the year.

History of previous inquiries
Clinton's impeachment inquiry took 72 calendar days, and Nixon's inquiry took 184 days (until he resigned). But, there is a difference between Trump's and Clinton's impeachment inquiry. Clinton's inquiry was preceded by the Starr-report (the result of an investigation that started four years prior). The Nixon inquiry was also preceded by a year-long investigation into the break-in in the DNC. At the moment, the impeachment inquiry into Trump seems more like a two in one (investigation and inquiry) into questions about abuse of power in foreign relations with Ukraine. Trump's inquiry started on September 24th. Investigators would at most have had 79 days, to pass the article before the end of the year. For a two in one inquiry, 79 days seems too short.

The scope of the inquiry
It is unclear (to me) how many grounds for impeachment will be brought together in the articles. How far will the commission go to prove obstruction? Will they aggregate findings from the Mueller report or from other investigations in order to substantiate the charges? Reading and agreeing can take a lot of time.
How many people will be heard? A number of people have been mentioned that could contribute to the proceedings but for whom it is unclear whether they are legally allowed to speak out (e.g. Bolton). Resolving this takes time.
As the whole world is watching this high stakes impeachment, there is great pressure to be precise and complete. Exhaustiveness takes time.

Timing of the public hearings
Public hearings have been announced to start November 11th. As there have been accusations recently that the inquiry is nontransparent, I expect a series of public hearings ("a circus").  A lead time of about one month for all the public hearings seems short given the number and the stature of the people involved. After the public hearings, it will take some time to bring together all the information into the articles of impeachment.

Conclusion
With everything that remains to be done, the chance of the house passing an article of impeachment against Trump before the new year is already very small. I simply do not see a compelling reason (Am I overlooking something?) for a very speedy process to make sure a vote on the articles of impeachment takes place on December 12 (or before).  The need for quality of the inquiry pushes the vote further into the future. The desire of some within the democratic party to influence public opinion with the narrative of impeachment also lengthens the process. 
In my opinion, there is no chance that the vote on the articles of impeachment takes place before the new year.

The classic GJopen question for the past year. It keeps coming back. I definitely struggle with this question. Not much precedent to look at and it seems to be driven by a few strong players (namely Pelosi and Trump). It's hard to try to get a read into their behavior - Pelosi's willingness to go for impeachment and Trump's willingness to do potentially impeachable acts. I think at this point, it is very clear that if Pelosi decides to put up a vote, the House of Representatives would pass an article of impeachment. The key question is will more information about Trump's behavior come out in the short term that necessitates an impeachment vote or will Pelosi decide the time is right and call for a vote with what information the Democrats have.  I think for the both those questions, the answer is probably not prior to January 1, 2020. It is certainly possible more information comes out about Trump's dealings, but I don't think there can be much worse information out there that hasn't been found. I don't think it'll change the timeline that much - in fact if new information comes out it may force Pelosi to recalculate. Probably more importantly, Pelosi and the Democrats have been very cautious and, I would say, political through this process. They haven't rushed into impeachment and seem content to focus on collecting info and having internal conversations for now. They know the senate will almost certainly not convict, so the whole impeachment process seems to be more about optics than anything else, essentially setting the Democrats up so that whoever the select as the nominee is in the best position to beat Trump in the 2020 election. Passing impeachment articles is the big political step, and I'm sure they'll wait till it has maximum impact, which I don't think will be in the next two months.  In addition, there is simply the calendar. As @Anneinak points out, there are only 22 legislative days. Also, putting this news out during the holiday season may dampen it's affect.  For comparison I looked at markets which give this question about a 50/50 chance [1].  The crowd here right now is 65%. I'll up my prediction a bit towards those, but not by too much.  [1] https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/4319/Will-Donald-Trump-be-impeached-by-year-end-2019
